docs.lead_paragraph: The Institute of Medicine says the American medical system loses $750 billion annually by squandering 30 cents of every dollar spent.

headline.seo: Waste and Promise Seen in U.S. Health Care System
headline.main: Study of U.S. Health Care System Finds Both Waste and Opportunity to Improve
headline.print_headline: Study of U.S. Health Care System Finds Both Waste and Opportunity to Improve

docs.abstract: Institute of Medicine reports that the American medical system loses $750 billion annually by squandering 30 cents of every dollar spent; health care experts and economists see an opportunity in all that waste and misuse to curb runaway health spending and to improve medical outcomes.
docs.snippet: The Institute of Medicine says the American medical system loses $750 billion annually by squandering 30 cents of every dollar spent.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A study indicated a slowing of costs for hospitals and doctors that collaborated to keep a defined group of patients healthier, a model promoted by the federal health care law.

headline.seo: Medical Care Networks Show Savings, Study Finds
headline.main: New Medical Care Networks Show Savings
headline.print_headline: New Medical Care Networks Show Savings

docs.abstract: Study in The Journal of the American Medical Association indicates that the creation of accountable care organizations, promoted by the federal health care law, holds promise for slowing the costs for hospitals and doctors treating the sickest, most expensive patients; more than 150 such groups now serve about 2.4 million Medicare patients.
docs.snippet: A study indicated a slowing of costs for hospitals and doctors that collaborated to keep a defined group of patients healthier, a model promoted by the federal health care law.

keywords.value: Journal of the American Medical Assn
keywords.name: organizations

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The average monthly benefit puts one around $3,000 above the poverty line, at what can be a vulnerable time of life.

headline.seo: The Tightwire Act of Living Only on Social Security
headline.main: The Tightwire Act of Living Only on Social Security
headline.print_headline: The Tightwire Act Of Living Only On Social Security

docs.abstract: Seniors in retirement relying solely on Social Security benefits must live on an inflexible budget that teeters on the brink of poverty and offers little security at a vulnerable time of life.
docs.snippet: The average monthly benefit puts one around $3,000 above the poverty line, at what can be a vulnerable time of life.

docs.lead_paragraph: As more people in the United States remain childless, lawyers are emphasizing the importance of setting up health care proxies and powers of attorney.

headline.seo: For Childless Older People, Legal and Logistical Challenges
headline.main: Childless and Aging? Time to Designate a Caregiver
headline.print_headline: Childless and Aging? Time to Designate a Caregiver

docs.abstract: Experts are emphasizing the importance of designating caregivers, setting up health proxies and powers of attorney as more people in the United States remain childless well into old age and retirement; with childless elderly, the lines of responsibility can be uncertain and plans need to be in place.
docs.snippet: As more people in the United States remain childless, lawyers are emphasizing the importance of setting up health care proxies and powers of attorney.

docs.lead_paragraph: A study by the Kaiser Family Foundation found that a family with employer-provided health insurance now pays just under $16,000 in annual premiums, an increase of about 4 percent from a year ago.

headline.seo: Health Care Premiums Rise Modestly, Report Says

docs.abstract: Kaiser Family Foundation study finds that a family with employer-provided health insurance now pays just under $16,000 in annual premiums, increase of 4 percent from a year ago; individual policies rose just 3 percent, to average of $5,615; Kaiser says lower premiums are sign that rise in health care costs continues to be modest, but is cautious about long-term implications.
docs.snippet: A study by the Kaiser Family Foundation found that a family with employer-provided health insurance now pays just under $16,000 in annual premiums, an increase of about 4 percent from a year ago.

docs.abstract: My husband and I agreed that we would terminate a fetus with genetic defects. We're too old to parent a special-needs child.
docs.snippet: My husband and I agreed that we would terminate a fetus with genetic defects. We're too old to parent a special-needs child.

docs.abstract: Political news from today's Times and around the Web, plus a look at the latest happenings in Washington.
docs.snippet: Political news from today's Times and around the Web, plus a look at the latest happenings in Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: Voters trying to understand the policies of Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan are going to have a harder time than ever.

headline.seo: The Shallow End of the Campaign
headline.main: The Shallow End of the Campaign
headline.print_headline: The Shallow End of the Campaign

docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan for actively trying to obscure their positions on many issues, as if a clear understanding of their beliefs about taxes, health care or spending would scare away voters; offers examples of the ways in which Republicans are sowing confusion.
docs.snippet: Voters trying to understand the policies of Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan are going to have a harder time than ever.
